content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Ah, this code very nice!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I solved it in exactly 5 minutes... I'm not great at "shortest" mode since my Ruby is so limited, but I bet code golfers could have some fun with this one

I think the problem is good, but it still lacks a bit of clarity about what to do if the time is an exact hour. I would recommend one of the following changes:
1) Change the wording in point #4 to say "If the time is closest to or exactly the start of the hour..."
2) Add a new condition for exact hour times in the goal, and add/change test cases. This could be something like "exactly [hour]", "[hour] o'clock", or just "[hour]".

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The statement is clear, test cases seem exhaustive and a solution can be coded pretty quickly

Rules 4 and 5 may be confusing; there is no explicit specification for what to classify the exact hour (XX:00) as, and the difference between the start hour mark and the end hour mark is not defined. I would suggest combining the two rules under "closest to the hour mark", then further branch from there (before/after the hour mark).

Not sure what the original format looked like before @5DN1L commented, but I would rephrase the rules to something like:
3. ... [NEXT hour].
4. Else, the time must be closest to the 0/60 minute mark. If the time lies <<strictly before>> the 0/60 minute mark, you'd say {{around [NEXT hour]}}. Otherwise, you'd say {{around [hour]}}.

As for the formatting of the [hour] variable, you could consider using your input notation in the problem statement:
You are given a time in <<12-hour format>> as [[h]]{{:}}[[mm]] {{AM}}/{{PM}}. Let [[nh]] be the <<next hour>> after [[h]] (ignoring AM/PM). E.g., [[h]] = 7 -> [[nh]] = 8; [[h]] = 12 -> [[nh]] = 1.
Your task is to convert...
1. ... {{half past}} [[h]].
2. ... {{quarter past}} [[h]].
3. ... {{quarter to}} [[nh]].
...

I've made most of the requested changes. For the formatting around [hour] in the problem statement, I've left the square brackets as they are. It was intentional to not format that text as a variable, as its purpose is to convey that there should be a number (the hour) in that spot, not a variable name. If you have a suggestion for a better way to communicate that, let me know. I've also left test/validator 7 unchanged, even though the test and the validator are the same - 12:53 is a specific edge case (if the program has an off-by-one error in the logic around 'looping' the hour over back around to 1), so I think it should be both a test and a validator. Lastly, I've made the specified changes to the other validators; I didn't previously understand that the validators should 'line up' with the corresponding tests; is there a reason you requested those specific changes to tests/validators 6 and 12?

Thanks.

Goal
* Please change all instances of "[hour]" and "[NEXT hour]" to "[[hour]]" and [[NEXT hour]].

* Please split point 4 into two separate points, one for “0 minute mark” and one for “60 minute mark (next hour)”, to make it clearer.

Input
* Please change ", including the hour, minute, and the AM/PM mark, but *not* the seconds" to:

as [[h]]{{:}}[[mm]] {{AM}}/{{PM}}, where [[h]] has no leading zero and [[mm]] is written with a leading zero if needed

Cases
* Some tests and their corresponding validators are the same. Please revise them so that they are different:
  • Test 7 and Validator 7
  • Test 11 and Validator 11
  • Test 12 and Validator 12

* Please update Test 4 so that the minutes are between 01 and 07, inclusive, similar to Validator 4.

* Test 6 and Validator 6: Please change the minutes to 15.

* Test 12 and Validator 12: Please change the minutes to 30 and adjust the output.

Thanks.

Thank you for your reply and for making the requested changes.

Sorry for the slightly delayed response. I didn't receive a notification from the system, and just a reminder that in order for me or others to be notified, you'll need to reply to an existing comment rather than starting a new one.

Regarding the use of "[hour]", since it's intended as a placeholder for the actual hour to be filled in, it should be treated as a variable rather than a constant. The current formatting would be more appropriate if the literal string "[hour]" were meant to appear in the output.

Also, @User123 made an excellent suggestion in the last part of their comment about how to format the [hour] variable. Please consider adopting those and updating the section accordingly.

While you mentioned that test/validator 7 was unchanged, I noticed that the test is now different from the validator, which is exactly what I was hoping to see and aligns with your intended scenario. As for the specific changes I requested for test/validators 6 and 12, the reason is that the scenarios covered by those times were also featured in other cases, whereas the updated times (falling exactly on 15 and 30 minutes) weren't tested anywhere else.
